THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 21, 1930

NORMAN THOMAS TO
SPEAK AT LUNCHEON
Mr. Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President
in the last election, and head
of the League of Industrial
Democracy, will be the -speaker at a Graduate Student-Faculty luncheon to be held next
Friday, March 28, at 12.30 p.
m., in Levering Hall.
Mr. Thomas has chosen for
his topic "The American Foreign Policy, With Special Reference to the London Conference." In his speech he will
bring out and discuss the question as to what is wrong with
the American foreign policy.
All graduate student and
faculty members are invited to
attend, as an interesting and
instructive discussion is promised.

PAYMENT DUE ON
YEAR BOOK PICTURES
Bills for pictures have been
sent out to the various activities and fraternities, according
to Gettemuller, musiness manager of the 1930 Hullabaloo.
It is of utmost importance that
these bills be paid as soon as
possible. If they are not paid
prior to April 1, the pictures
of the fraternities or activities,
whose payments have not been
forthcoming, will not appear
in the yearbook.
Also all copy on clubs, activities, or fraternities must
be in by March 25.

EDITORIALS

ASSEMBLIES
proverb of "give a man an inch and he'll take an ell" has

HE old
Tproven
true in the case of freshman regulations. All the onerous

duties that have been imposed on yearlings in the past were withdrawn
last fall, but compulsory attendance at assemblies was retained. It was
thought that the freshmen naturally would comply with this simple
ruling in view of the fact that it would be the only duty they would
be called upon to perform. But just as many frosh cut assemblies as
in years gone by. Nor are the sophomores any better.
The regrettable feature of the small attendance at assemblies is that
it gives the speakers, many of whom have no connection with the university, a very uncomplimentary opinion of Hopkins. To speak to an
audience of fifty in a school whose undergraduate enrollment numbers
approximately eight hundred is disconcerting to say the least. Furthermore, a guest speaker could very justifiably consider the sparseness of
the gathering a. direct personal insult.
The numbers of the two lower classes should feel grateful for the
freedom of action allowed them at Hopkins in comparison with other
universities and consequently should not fail to comply with the one
request made of them, namely, to attend assemblies regularly.

MANY ATTACK MEN
Attempts To Build Team
Result In Changes
Harry Love, who won his letter
last year in lacrosse at in home,
has been changed to the defense in
one of the most important steps
taken in the building of this year's
team. In all probability he will continue at cover point all season.
The defense is not entirely new
to Love as he played cover point
two years at Polytechnic. Purnell
Hall, captain of the Blue Jay stickmen this year, played point at Poly
the same years so that two should
work well together.
Love's excellent stickwork and
the wealth of material for the attack are given as the reasons for
the change. Harry can handle a
stick with either his right or left
hand and his size is expected to be
of greater value on the close defense. In his freshman year at Hopkins he was substitute goal keeper.
but last year earned his letter at in
home as stated before;

the South Room of Levering Hall
from 4:30 to 6:30. All who can possibly be there are urged to attend.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 21, 1930

NORMAN THOMAS TO
SPEAK AT LUNCHEON
Mr. Norman Thomas, Socialist candidate for President
in the last election, and head
of the League of Industrial
Democracy, will be the -speaker at a Graduate Student-Faculty luncheon to be held next
Friday, March 28, at 12.30 p.
m., in Levering Hall.
Mr. Thomas has chosen for
his topic "The American Foreign Policy, With Special Reference to the London Conference." In his speech he will
bring out and discuss the question as to what is wrong with
the American foreign policy.
All graduate student and
faculty members are invited to
attend, as an interesting and
instructive discussion is promised.

THE NORMAN,REMINGTON CO.

EDITORIALS

ASSEMBLIES
proverb of "give a man an inch and he'll take an ell" has

HE old
Tproven
true in the case of freshman regulations. All the onerous

duties that have been imposed on yearlings in the past were withdrawn
last fall, but compulsory attendance at assemblies was retained. It was
thought that the freshmen naturally would comply with this simple
ruling in view of the fact that it would be the only duty they would
be called upon to perform. But just as many frosh cut assemblies as
in years gone by. Nor are the sophomores any better.
The regrettable feature of the small attendance at assemblies is that
it gives the speakers, many of whom have no connection with the university, a very uncomplimentary opinion of Hopkins. To speak to an
audience of fifty in a school whose undergraduate enrollment numbers
approximately eight hundred is disconcerting to say the least. Furthermore, a guest speaker could very justifiably consider the sparseness of
the gathering a. direct personal insult.
The numbers of the two lower classes should feel grateful for the
freedom of action allowed them at Hopkins in comparison with other
universities and consequently should not fail to comply with the one
request made of them, namely, to attend assemblies regularly.

MANY ATTACK MEN
Attempts To Build Team
Result In Changes
Harry Love, who won his letter
last year in lacrosse at in home,
has been changed to the defense in
one of the most important steps
taken in the building of this year's
team. In all probability he will continue at cover point all season.
The defense is not entirely new
to Love as he played cover point
two years at Polytechnic. Purnell
Hall, captain of the Blue Jay stickmen this year, played point at Poly
the same years so that two should
work well together.
Love's excellent stickwork and
the wealth of material for the attack are given as the reasons for
the change. Harry can handle a
stick with either his right or left
hand and his size is expected to be
of greater value on the close defense. In his freshman year at Hopkins he was substitute goal keeper.
but last year earned his letter at in
home as stated before;

Tea Dance Thursday
At Levering Hall
The Faculty-Graduate Student
Tea Dance this week is planned especially to provide an opportunity
for husbands and wives of members
of the Faculty and Graduate group
who are not otherwise connected
with the University to meet each
other and become acquainted with
the academic circle. It will be held
as usual on Thursday afternoon in
the South Room of Levering Hall
from 4:30 to 6:30. All who can possibly be there are urged to attend.

The bowling tournament has been
brought to a conclusion after several
weeks of close competition. Both divisions ended in ties in the preliminary round. In the playoff Chemistry defended its position against the
bowlers from the Political Science
Department. Classical defeated the
Economists to enter the finals. In
the final match which was played
last Thursday, the Classical team
succesfully defended their position
and clinched the J. D. Clark trophy
by defeating the Chemistry team

victors at a dinner to be held April

Following appears a summary of
the meets held in 1930: On January 11, the University of Delaware
defeated the Johns Hopkins University, at Delaware, by the score of
47-19; on February 8, Hopkins lost
to the Baltimore Y. M. C. A., at the
latter's pool, 56-10; at Gettysburg,
on March 6, Hopkins was defeated
by the Gettysburg College, 35-31;
Franklin and Marshal decisively defeated Hopkins at Franklin anld
Marshall on March 8, to the tune
of 56 to 10. A this point the fortunes of the Hopkins squad appeared to brighten; on March 11,
Hopkins defeated Gettysburg College at the Knights of Columbus
pool, 42-24; on March 15, Hopkins
lost to Catholic U, also at the
Knights of Columbus pool by the
rather close score of 28-38; and on
March 17, George Washington University was defeated at Washington,
34-26; a summary of this last meet
appears above. The improvement
shown by Johns Hopkins in the last
three engagements speaks well for
the future success of the swimming
team.
